emotion_OR: The above system seems fair. While that won't make Chris happy, etc., it shouldn't result in negative feelings either.
trust_OR: The manager should know how important the different components are, and the algorithm applies known history.
algorithm definition: It's a set of instructions that a computer uses to calculate/solve problems.

fairness_OR: Using the algorithm to flag potential problems is an effective first step. But the computer cannot evaluate each and every human factor involved in all employee-customer calls.
emotion_OR: If Chris effectively dealt with his customers, he might be disappointed that a human supervisor is not recognizing his effort. If Chris had a problem with one or more customers, he may be disappointed that no one is training him on how to deal with "problem" customers.
trust_OR: The algorithm may be an effective "first step" in the evaluation process, but there are far too many factors to rely on the algorithm alone.
algorithm definition: Algorithms are decision-processing programs used with computers to arrive at solutions or answers.

MC Human OR: The manager determined the importance of the machine component and the algorithm predicted the failure rate and assigns Chris to the maintenance task.
fairness_OR: I think it is fair because this is probably part of Chris' job responsibilities. In addition, careful thought and planning goes into assigning Chris a maintenance task as both the manager and the algorithm serve as a check and balance as to what might break down next.
emotion_OR: I think Chris would be happy to do his job and to fix things proactively to maintain a well run facility
trust_OR: It is based on past history of machine breakdowns so it is probably accurate for the most part
algorithm definition: They are a  process or sequence of actions that do something

MC Human OR: The manager imputed the variables, the computer calculated it and the manager used that info to make his decision.

emotion_OR: It is probably what he had expected.
trust_OR: There is always computer error, but there aren't very many variables to have to lean on the computer to know this is the correct decision.

MC Human OR: The algorithm determines what will need maintenance, and the manager assigns it to the worker
fairness_OR: I figure the algorithm can tell when a piece of the machinery is nearing the end of its life, and so Chris is doing preventative maintenance. That's better than waiting until the component fails, which could shut down the production for no telling how long.
emotion_OR: I figure the individual would rather wait for the part to break rather than doing preventative maintenance, so I imagine Chris would feel frustrated about working on parts that are seemingly ok, even though the algorithm shows that they could be nearing the end of their lives.
trust_OR: I think the algorithm is going to take a lot more aspects into consideration than a human would. The algorithm is probably going to monitor how long it's been since the part has been serviced, how much usage the part has had, and the history of that component in the workflow. I also figure that components that are more important will be given more attention so something that is extremely vital to the workflow is going to have the best preventative maintenance to prevent failure, while something that is less vital, but still important, is still going to be monitored but other aspects of the process will be prioritized if need be.
algorithm definition: An algorithm is a complicated set of instructions to figure something out. In this case the algorithm would probably take time since last maintenance, how vital the component is to the process, the history of that component (like how long it's lasted in the past), and various other things to calculate when a component will be needing maintenance or replacement.
